title: 112_hr628
content: Temporary reinstatement of the Emergency Contingency Fund for State Temporary Assistance for Needy Families programs. The Emergency Contingency Fund for State Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Programs is established with $20 billion appropriated for fiscal year 2011, remaining available through fiscal year 2018. The Emergency Contingency Fund for State Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Programs, established with $20 billion appropriated for fiscal year 2011 through 2018, will provide grants to States in each fiscal year from 2011 to 2018. The Secretary is limited from making grants after fiscal year 2018. Grants will be made to States that request them and meet the requirements related to caseload increases. The Emergency Contingency Fund provides grants to States from 2011 to 2018. States must meet caseload increase requirements to receive grants. The grant amount is 80% of the increase in assistance caseload from the previous fiscal year. The Emergency Contingency Fund provides grants to States from 2011 to 2018 based on caseload increase requirements. The grant amount is 80% of the increase in assistance caseload from the previous fiscal year. The Emergency Contingency Fund provides grants to States based on caseload increase requirements. States must meet non-recurrent short term expenditure requirements to qualify for the grant. The Emergency Contingency Fund provides grants to States based on caseload increase requirements, with non-recurrent short term benefits in the corresponding quarter in the preceding fiscal year. The grant amount is 80 percent of the excess described, and there is a separate grant related to increased expenditures for subsidized employment from 2011 to 2018. The Emergency Contingency Fund provides grants to States based on caseload increase requirements for subsidized employment. States must exceed total expenditures from the previous fiscal year to qualify for the grant. The Emergency Contingency Fund provides grants to States based on caseload increase requirements for subsidized employment. The grant amount is 80 percent of the excess described in the clause. The Secretary has the authority to adjust data and collect necessary data to ensure comparability among States. The Secretary may develop a mechanism for collecting expenditure data and set deadlines for revisions. The total amount payable to a single State shall not exceed 50 percent of the annual State family assistance grant. States can only use the funds as authorized by section 404. Implementation should be done as quickly as possible, with guidance to States. This subsection also applies to Indian tribes. The subsection applies to Indian tribes with approved tribal family assistance plans under section 412, similar to how it applies to States. Definitions include 'average monthly assistance caseload' and 'qualified State expenditures'. Section 1108(a)(2) of the Social Security Act is amended to include additional sections. Section 407(b)(3)(A)(i) is also amended to eliminate the modification of caseload reduction credit. Effective October 1, 2018, amendments are made to the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, including the elimination of certain provisions related to caseload reduction credit. Additionally, Section 403 of the Social Security Act is amended to remove a subsection. Amendments to the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 include changes to Section 1108(a)(2) of the Social Security Act, removing limitations on total payments to territories.
